subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Macbeth
msgSnippet: Hello Ewout, Since copying results are boring and tedious, i decided to run my own frequency analysis.  On school term-break, and slightly bored, i ran the
messageBody:
Hello Ewout,

Since copying results are boring and tedious, i decided to run my
own frequency analysis. On school term-break, and slightly bored, i
ran the analysis on a more representive sample of Shavian texts. The
texts come mostly from the Yahoo Shavian group download area.

The results are different from, but similar to Scott Harrison's
analysis. However, since more than one transliterator is represented
here, the results should be a more accurate measure of actual
real-life usage.

The entire frequency results are attached, but for a more beautified
version, along with the textual corpus and perl analysis script, goto
<http://www.wpi.edu/~flicken/language/shavian/freq.php>.

Regards,

Brian Roberts

PS. If anyone has a larger, or more organized corpus of text, let me
know... I'd love to run the analysis on something bigger.


2002-03-06.1945 skribis Ewout Stam <teraiten@...>:
> If you could kindly send me the whole list, my computer at home and the ones
> at school don't run IE 9.0 and installing the font didn't help. All I see is
> square blocks.
>
> > A good place to start might be the Shavian Letter Frequency Analysis
> >for Scott's Shavian Documents
> ><http://www.mithrandir.com/Shavian/ShavianFrequencyCount.html>. The
> >frequency analysis covers the texts transliterated by Scott Harrison
> >available at his site
> ><http://www.mithrandir.com/Shavian/Shavian.html>.
> >
> > The sample size is ~150,000 characters, so the trends should be
> >clear. Surprisingly, schwa (ado) is 7th on the list. Perhaps this is
> >due to a bias of the author's spelling?... Here's the (pruned) list:
> >
> > 9.18% Nun
> > 9.07% Tot
> > 8.24% If
> > 6.56% So
> > 5.40% Dead
> > 5.17% Loll
> > 4.96% Ado
> > 4.19% THey
> > ...
> > ...
> > 0.33% Yea
> > 0.00% Ah
> >
> >
> > With the appropriate corpus of texts, the frequency analysis should
> >be fairly simple. A simple Perl script would do the job (perl -e
> >'while(<>){chomp; for(split/\s*/){$f{$_}++}} for(keys %f) { print "$_ =
> >$f{$_} \n"; }')....
>
> I have no idea how to run perl, let alone program in perl. Perhaps somebody
> else's interested.
>
> >
> >Regards,
> >
> > Brian Roberts
>
>
>

>

>

--
Ludi kun iu ludon de pugnoj.
